notes: Networks may be overloaded. Prioritize emergency communications.
They may contain debris, chemicals, or hidden hazards.
Water may be deeper or more dangerous than it looks.
Avoid downed wires and don’t touch wet electrical equipment.

after.step: Stay away from damaged structures and roads
notes: Buildings may collapse and roads could be unstable.

after.step: Seek medical help if you're injured or sick
notes: Contact emergency services or go to the nearest medical facility if possible.
Take photos, make an inventory, and contact your local insurer or assistance service.

title: Volcano
description: A volcano is an opening in the Earth's surface that allows lava, gas, and debris to escape.
During an eruption, lava and debris can travel fast and destroy everything in their path.
Volcanic ash can spread far and cause breathing problems and damage buildings.

before.step: Find out if you live near an active volcano.
notes: Check local hazard maps or ask local authorities about volcanic risks in your area.

before.step: Know your local evacuation zones and shelter locations.
notes: Ask emergency services or local authorities for evacuation plans and safe shelters away from ash and lava.

before.step: Stock up on essentials in advance.
notes: Include food, water, medications, dust masks, pet supplies, and cleaning products for several days.

before.step: Create and practice a family evacuation and communication plan.
notes: Include pets and livestock. Plan where to meet if separated.

before.step: Have a plan to stay indoors if ashfall is expected.
notes: Close windows, seal doors, and prepare to shelter-in-place if needed.

before.step: If you have breathing problems, consult your doctor.
notes: Ash can worsen asthma and other lung conditions — have any needed medications ready.
Store in a waterproof container or save password-protected digital copies online.
Some policies do not cover volcanic damage. Check what’s included in your plan.

during.step: Stay informed and follow local alerts.
notes: Use a trusted source of emergency updates. Listen for instructions to evacuate or shelter.

during.step: Evacuate early if told to do so.
notes: Do not wait until the last moment — lava and ash can spread quickly.

during.step: Avoid areas near the volcano or downwind from it.
notes: Ash and debris move with wind and gravity, especially in river valleys.

during.step: Shelter indoors if safe and you have supplies.
notes: Seal openings to prevent ash from entering. Wait for official updates before going out.

during.step: If outside, protect your lungs, eyes, and skin.
notes: Wear a well-fitting mask (like an N95), goggles, and long sleeves to reduce ash exposure.
Ash can reduce visibility and clog vehicle engines.

after.step: Wait for official word before going outside or returning home.
notes: Even if the eruption stops, hazards like ash or mudflows may still exist.

after.step: Use text or social media to check in with family.
notes: Phone lines may be overwhelmed — save calls for emergencies.
Ash on roads reduces traction and can damage your vehicle.

after.step: Avoid ash if you have respiratory issues.
notes: Use a mask indoors if ash enters your home. Ventilate only when air is clear.

after.step: Be cautious when cleaning up ash.
notes: Ash is slippery and heavy. Do not climb on roofs without training. Wear protective gear.

after.step: Keep children away from ash cleanup.
notes: Ash can be harmful if touched or inhaled, especially for young children.

title: Wildfire
description: Wildfires are fast-spreading fires in natural areas like forests or grasslands.
They can destroy homes, wildlife, and entire communities.

notes: Enable local emergency alerts and weather notifications on your phone.
Sign up for regional text alerts or community warning systems if available.
Poor air can harm sensitive groups. Limit outdoor activity during smoky conditions.
Include family, pets, and frequent locations like work or school.
Practice the route ahead of time.
Store digital copies of ID and insurance in a secure cloud location.
Clear dry leaves and debris at least 30 feet from buildings.
Seal a room with no outside air for smoky days. A portable air purifier helps.
Use fire-resistant materials where possible.
Plan where to go and how you’ll get there.
Include pets in your evacuation plans.
Include food, water, masks, a flashlight, chargers, and a first aid kit.
Slowly stock up in advance if needed.

before.step: Store and handle flammable items carefully.
notes: Keep products like aerosols and alcohol-based cleaners away from heat.
N95 or similar masks protect your lungs from smoke particles.
Buy power banks in case of outages or evacuation.
Follow instructions from local authorities immediately.
Shelter with friends or family if possible.
Only use official shelters if you have no alternative.

during.step: If trapped, call emergency services and turn on lights to help rescuers find you.
notes: Stay inside and away from windows if you can’t leave.
Stay indoors, seal doors/windows, and use an air purifier.
If outside, wear an N95 mask or equivalent.
Set AC to recirculate if available.

during.step: If sick, contact your healthcare provider and avoid going out.
notes: Shelter in place unless it's an emergency.

after.step: Return only when officials say it’s safe.
notes: Re-entering too soon can expose you to hidden dangers like gas leaks, structural instability, or toxic fumes.

after.step: Avoid hazards like hot ash, smoldering debris, or unstable trees.
notes: Even after the immediate danger passes, these hazards can cause injuries or reignite fires.
Use gloves, sturdy shoes, and long sleeves.
Wet debris, wear a respirator, and avoid cleanup if you have breathing issues.

after.step: Document damage with photos and contact your insurance provider.
notes: Take clear, wide-angle shots of structural damage and valuables before moving anything for insurance claims.

after.step: Text or message loved ones to let them know you're safe.
notes: Avoid phone calls unless it’s an emergency.

title: Winter Weather
description: Winter storms can bring extreme cold, snow, ice, and strong winds. They increase risks of accidents, hypothermia, frostbite, and power outages. Children, older adults, sick individuals, and pets are especially vulnerable.

notes: Winter Storm Warning = Dangerous weather happening soon or now.
Winter Storm Watch = Possible severe weather within 1–2 days.
Advisory = Less severe, but still risky—be cautious.
Seal windows and doors to keep heat in.
Insulate pipes to prevent freezing.
Install smoke and carbon monoxide alarms with battery backups.
Stock food, water, flashlights, batteries, medications, and pet items.
Have enough for several days without power.
Keep it fueled. Pack blankets, food, water, flashlight, jumper cables, and warm clothes.
Limit outdoor time. If outside, wear warm layers.
Watch for signs of frostbite (numbness, pale skin) and hypothermia (shivering, confusion, slurred speech).
Take breaks when shoveling snow. Overexertion can trigger heart problems.
Never use an oven or stove for heat.
Use generators only outside, far from windows.
Install carbon monoxide detectors.
Stay inside. Run the engine periodically to stay warm. Keep the exhaust pipe clear of snow.
Watch for fallen power lines, icy surfaces, and damage to your home.
Continue using generators safely if power is still out.
Check in on neighbors, especially the elderly or those with health conditions.

title: Epidemic
description: An epidemic is a sudden increase in the number of cases of an infectious disease in a specific area or population.
It can disrupt healthcare, strain resources, and lead to illness or death if not properly managed. Preparedness and early action are key to reducing spread and protecting vulnerable groups.

before.step: Stay informed about common diseases and outbreaks.
notes: Follow official health sources and your local health ministry.
Sign up for public health alerts if available.
Keep your routine immunizations up to date.
During a known epidemic (e.g., flu, measles, COVID-19), get targeted vaccines if eligible.

before.step: Build a personal and household hygiene plan.
notes: Stock soap, alcohol-based hand sanitizers, disinfectants, tissues, and face masks.
Practice regular handwashing and cough/sneeze etiquette.

before.step: Prepare for isolation or quarantine if needed.
notes: Have at least 14 days’ worth of essential supplies: food, water, medicine, hygiene products.
Identify a separate room for isolation in your home, if possible.
Plan for remote work or school if closures happen.
Create special plans for the elderly, chronically ill, or immunocompromised.
Minimize their exposure during peak transmission periods.
Comply with movement restrictions, mask mandates, or stay-at-home orders.
Seek testing and treatment through official channels.
Wash hands frequently for at least 20 seconds.
Avoid touching your face, especially eyes, nose, and mouth.
Maintain distance from people, especially in crowded or poorly ventilated areas.
Stay alert for signs of illness (fever, cough, fatigue, loss of smell/taste, etc.).
Seek medical advice early if symptoms develop.

during.step: Use masks and protective equipment correctly.
notes: Wear masks in public settings, especially indoors or around vulnerable people.
Do not reuse disposable masks; wash reusable ones properly.
Stay connected with family and friends through digital means.
Take breaks from news and focus on daily routines.
Reach out for help if feeling overwhelmed or anxious.
Maintain hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette.
Stay home when sick to prevent future outbreaks.

after.step: Get post-epidemic medical care if needed.
notes: Check in with healthcare providers for any lingering symptoms or missed appointments.
Follow rehabilitation programs if you were seriously affected.
Restock used supplies and strengthen emergency plans.
Discuss lessons learned with your household or community.

after.step: Watch for resurgence or secondary waves.
notes: Keep monitoring news and updates from health authorities.
Be ready to resume precautions if cases rise again.
